instruction: How were the image classifiers used in the study to generate training samples for mapping the invasive pompom weed using hyperspectral data?
Output:
In the study, three image classifiers were used to generate training samples for mapping the invasive pompom weed using hyperspectral data. The image classifiers used were the maximum likelihood classifier (MLC), support vector machine (SVM), and spectral angle mapper (SAM). These classifiers were selected to represent each of the three types of image classifiers under investigation in the study.

The SAM, MLC, and SVM classifiers were applied to the hyperspectral data to classify the pixels into different classes, including the class containing pompom weed. The classifiers were trained using minimal ground control points as reference samples. The aim was to assess how these classifiers could accurately generate a large number of training samples from minimal ground control points to train machine learning algorithms for mapping the invasive pompom weed.

The results of the study showed that the SAM, MLC, and SVM classifiers had pixel-based classification accuracies of 87%, 73%, and 67% for the pompom-containing pixels class, respectively. Additionally, an independent field verification for the SAM classification yielded an overall mapping accuracy of 92% for the pompom-containing pixels class.
